TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua i Kałuyung azua ła Paiquluvuy a namasan pałi, aya a tjautsikel.
izoa i Kaljoyong azoa lja Paiqolovoy a namasan palji, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: There was a person of the Paiquluvuy family in Kałuyung who became an evil-eye man, according to the story.

S.FORM: nu kivangavang azua, izua patsunan a sasiq anema; paridiw a matsay, aya.
no kivangavang azoa, izoa paconan a sasiq anema; paridiw a macay, aya.
S.TRANSL: As he walked about, ants or anything else he saw died, they say.

S.FORM: "aku mayaya sun? nasa uri nakuya sun," aya a łamadju.
"ako mayaya son? nasa ori nakoya son," aya a ljamadjo.
S.TRANSL: “Why are you like that? You’re going to be someone bad,” people said.

S.FORM: sivaik a sema pana; uri paqayam tua tsiqaw.
sivaik a sema pana; ori paqayam toa ciqaw.
S.TRANSL: They took him to the river to see the fish;

S.FORM: manu ka kiqenetj tua tsiqaw, matsay anga.
mano ka kiqenetj toa ciqaw, macay anga.
S.TRANSL: and when he looked at the fish they died.

S.FORM: "ai nasa uri ka pałi sun," aya zazua salasaladj.
"ai nasa ori ka palji son," aya zazoa salasaladj.
S.TRANSL: “Oh! It seems you’re becoming an evil-eye man,” said his companions.

S.FORM: saka tsemikel a sema umaq.
saka cemikel a sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: So they went back home.

S.FORM: łakua sivaik a sema pasa navanavał.
ljakoa sivaik a sema pasa navanavalj.
S.TRANSL: But they took him down south,

S.FORM: sa san tapavan.
sa san tapavan.
S.TRANSL: and made him a house.

S.FORM: saka izuanga timadju a matsidił.
saka izoanga timadjo a macidilj.
S.TRANSL: And he was there by himself.

S.FORM: "azua nu kiteveł tua salasaladj, azua semengats," aya.
"azoa no kitevelj toa salasaladj, azoa semengac," aya.
S.TRANSL: “When he is with his former companions he is dangerous,” they said.

S.FORM: avanu sikitjukuda.
avano sikitjokoda.
S.TRANSL: That’s why he had to live apart.

S.FORM: saka zua pałi a papatsay timadju, marekutj a małaqałan a qaliqali.
saka zoa palji a papacay timadjo, marekotj a maljaqaljan a qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: So because the evil-eye man could kill, people of other villages were afraid.

S.FORM: saka avanu sipakitjavilił tua vava tua vutjuł tua qavay tua kinsa, aya.
saka avano sipakitjavililj toa vava toa votjolj toa qavay toa kinsa, aya.
S.TRANSL: So they took turns to give him beer, meat, dumplings and other food, they say.

S.FORM: manu nasa masupil anga azua małaqałan, sa sunasii nua se Vungaliz, sa łułu-i.
mano nasa masopil anga azoa maljaqaljan, sa sonasii noa se Vongaliz, sa ljoljo-i.
S.TRANSL: But it seems the people got tired of it, and the people of Vungaliz killed him and picked up (his head);

S.FORM: manu sivaik azua tjałuzua i pana i Tjuakalangan.
mano sivaik azoa tjaljozoa i pana i Tjoakalangan.
S.TRANSL: and took it to the river at Tjuakalangan.

S.FORM: "tja qayamaw," aya zazua.
"tja qayamaw," aya zazoa.
S.TRANSL: “Let’s have a look,” they said.

S.FORM: manu ka suqulengan a mudingan, manu matsay a se Vungaliz.
mano ka soqolengan a modingan, mano macay a se Vongaliz.
S.TRANSL: But when they uncovered the face, the Vungaliz people died.

S.FORM: saka matsidił anga a pinatseqisan a pi tsungal, aya.
saka macidilj anga a pinaceqisan a pi congal, aya.
S.TRANSL: One survived wounded in the knee from his glare, they say.

S.FORM: saka matsidił anga nu pakaqiaw sema umaq i Vungaliz.
saka macidilj anga no pakaqiaw sema omaq i Vongaliz.
S.TRANSL: He went off alone back home to Vungaliz calling for help.

S.FORM: "matsay amen," aya, aya a tjautsikel.
"macay amen," aya, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: “We’re being killed,” he said, according to the story.
